Introduction

Acute epididymitis is a common cause of acute scrotal pain characterized by inflammation of the epididymis, the tubular structure located on the posterior aspect of each testicle (

figure 1
).  Acute epididymitis is most often caused by bacterial organisms that ascend from the urethra; the identity of the pathogen varies by patient age.  Typical clinical findings include the gradual onset of unilateral testicular pain and swelling and epididymal tenderness on examination.  Broad-spectrum antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment.

Pathophysiology



Most cases of epididymitis occur when genitourinary pathogens travel in a retrograde fashion from the urethra to the vas deferens and into the epididymis.  The most likely bacterial organisms vary by patient age and risk factors.



  • Men age <35:  Most cases of epididymitis are caused by sexually transmitted infections, specifically Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis.  Bacteria enter the genitourinary tract during unprotected intercourse then seed the epididymis, causing inflammation and infection.
  • Men age â‰¥35:  Epididymitis is often associated with bladder outlet obstruction (eg, benign prostatic hyperplasia), which increases the risk of retrograde flow of infected urine (bacteriuria).  Typical organisms include Escherichia coli and other coliform bacteria associated with urinary tract infections.


Although bacterial infection is the most common etiology, repetitive movements (eg, jumping, running), trauma, autoimmune disorders, or viral infections (eg, mumps) can also cause epididymitis.

Risk factors



  • Sexually transmitted infections
  • Urinary tract infections
  • Anatomical abnormalities such as prostate enlargement, urethral strictures, or congenital abnormalities that increase the risk of urinary backflow
  • Prostate procedures, because manipulation during prostate biopsy or surgery can predispose to epididymitis
  • Urethral catheterization, due to increased risk of bacterial entry into the genitourinary system

Clinical presentation

Symptoms



  • Acute scrotal/testicular pain:  typically posterior, unilateral, and gradual in onset
  • Dysuria, frequency, and urgency:  generally occur when urinary tract infection is the source
  • Urethral discharge:  may be seen with sexually transmitted infections

Physical examination



  • Tenderness along the epididymis (posterior superior aspect of the testicle)
  • Scrotal swelling, erythema, and warmth
  • Pain improves with elevation of the testes (ie, positive Prehn sign):  Manual elevation of the hemiscrotum removes the weight of the testicle from the inflamed epididymis.
  • Intact cremasteric reflex:  Stroking the inner thigh causes spontaneous contraction of the cremasteric muscle, which elevates the ipsilateral testicle.
  • With or without suprapubic tenderness (present if epididymitis is related to cystitis)

Diagnosis



Epididymitis should be considered in any patient with acute scrotal pain.  All patients with acute scrotal pain require the following evaluation:



  • Urgent testicular ultrasound:  the most important initial step required to rule out testicular torsion (a urologic surgical emergency that may present similarly to epididymitis).  Ultrasound also allows for visualization of an enlarged and hypervascular epididymis, which supports the diagnosis of epididymitis.
  • Urinalysis and urine culture:  to assess for urinary tract infection and determine the causative bacterial organism.
  • Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT):  for sexually transmitted infections.  Patients at low risk for sexually transmitted infections (eg, older patient, monogamous relationship) may not always require NAAT, particularly if urinalysis suggests urinary infection (eg, positive nitrites, bacteriuria).

Differential diagnosis



  • Testicular torsion (
    figure 2
    ):  occurs when the testicle twists on its spermatic cord, abruptly compromising its blood supply.  Pain is usually severe, rapid in onset, and associated with nausea and vomiting.  The cremasteric reflex is typically absent, presumably due to abnormal mobility and position of the twisted testicle (eg, horizontal and high-riding), and manual elevation of the testicle exacerbates pain (ie, negative Prehn sign) because it further impairs blood flow from the spermatic cord.  Ultrasound reveals a lack of blood flow to the affected testicle.
  • Inguinal hernia (
    figure 3
    ):  may be associated with scrotal swelling and discomfort, but symptoms are usually aggravated by straining or lifting, and examination reveals a characteristic, often reducible, bulge in the scrotal sac.
  • Mumps orchitis:  involves inflammation of the testicle due to viral infection.  Scrotal symptoms (eg, erythema, swelling) may be similar to epididymitis, but testicular pain is often more severe.  Patients also typically have associated malaise, myalgias, headache, and parotid swelling.

Management



Treatment is determined by the most likely source of infection.

Epididymitis related to sexually transmitted infections 



  • Intramuscular ceftriaxone (single dose) and oral doxycycline to cover N gonorrhoeae and C trachomatis
  • Evaluation for other sexually transmitted infections (eg, HIV, syphilis)
  • Recommending testing and treatment for all sexual partners
  • Retesting 3 months after treatment to assess for reinfection
  • Test of cure (after antibiotic completion) is typically unnecessary unless there are persistent symptoms or concerns about medication noncompliance

Epididymitis related to urinary tract source



  • Fluoroquinolones to cover enteric organisms (eg, E coli).  Antibiotics are adjusted based on urine culture results. 


Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications, bed rest, and scrotal elevation may help alleviate symptoms until the resolution of infection.

Prognosis



With prompt diagnosis and appropriate treatment, epididymitis generally resolves without long-term sequelae.  However, delayed diagnosis or inadequate treatment can lead to epididymal abscess, orchitis (infection/inflammation involving the testicle), impaired fertility, or sepsis (in the case of severe infection).

Summary



Epididymitis  is a common etiology for acute scrotal pain and is most often caused by a bacterial infection of the epididymis (

).  The source of infection varies based on patient age and risk factor profile (eg, urinary tract infection vs sexually transmitted infection).  Clinical findings include posterior testicular pain and tenderness, scrotal swelling, an intact cremasteric reflex, and improvement in symptoms with scrotal elevation.  Confirmation requires urinalysis/urine culture and nucleic acid amplification testing for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis.  Treatment involves broad-spectrum oral antibiotics.
